channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Namaste and a Beach Day - Perl Position in California
item.description: Drab walls. Fluorescent lighting. A window overlooking the parking lot and Tedâ€™s rusty old Corollaâ€”does this sound like your nine-to-five nightmare? Then you donâ€™t want to miss this opportunity in beautiful Irvine, California, where your new office has views of the coast, the sea, and the Saddleback. Hello, mountain majesty!

item.title: Put your Perl skills into action in a young, green city that leaves more greenbacks in your pocket.
item.description: Youâ€™ll be working for a Pittsburgh-based hosting company, well-known and well-respected within Perl circles. Serving over 120 countries worldwide and with their skin in the game for a quarter century, youâ€™ll be joining a squad with a smorgasbord of coding talent helping a plethora of businesses at scale.

item.title: Sick of jobs lacking purpose? This Perl job literally cures the worldâ€™s ills
item.description: Want to help push forward the boundaries of medical science? Join a team of brilliant minds developing the software to allow scientists to cure diseases. Based out of the leafy city of Cambridge â€“ a home for everyone from Darwin to Hawking to you.

item.title: Revolutionize and Democratize the Job Recruitment Game
item.description: An Irvine, California-based software company is looking for developers to help revolutionize and democratize the job recruitment game. If youâ€™re proficient in Perl and enthusiastic about other platforms, such as React or Angular on front-end and Node.js or Python on backend, this could be your opportunity to streamline the job market by helping recruiters make better decisions about candidates.

item.title: Do some good in the world â€“ Perl developers required for a charity and giving-focused team in Kent
item.description: Want to do something good for once? Join the Kickstarter of the charity world, supporting activists and causes around the world. Youâ€™ll be working in Perl to support a range of their highly successful charity and giving-focused projects.

item.description: August 16-17, 2019 FlÃ¶rli Olten, Switzerland

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 12: Euclid Numbers and Common Paths
item.description: Yozen, being new to the Perl Weekly Challenge, has definitely impressed me with his ability to talk through his solution. Not many people can do that.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 012
item.description: Mark's solution in Perl6 is full of detailed comments and easy to follow.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge # 12: Euclid's Numbers and Directories
item.description: Laurent's blog ideal for anyone wants to learn Perl6. Such a brilliant writing any Perl5 hacker can follow easily.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 12 â€“ Euclid Numbers
item.description: Joelle sharing her solution to the Euclid number challenge. A very informative blog.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 012: Non-Prime Euclid Numbers and the Common Path
item.description: Choroba came up with helper module to solve the challenge. Check out his blog to find out why.

item.title: Common Paths and an issue with postderef?
item.description: I simply love the journey and how Dave progressed through.

item.title: Euclid and Reduce
item.description: Dave always present the solution like a kids play. He has the ability to make the difficult challenge appears easy.

item.title: The Euclid Path with Perl 6
item.description: The line-by-line explanation of the solution by Arne Sommer is unmatachable.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 012
item.description: Adam, as always, came up with detailed solution for the challenge 012.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 012
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 013
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Grant Proposal: A Complete Perl 6 Course with Exercises
item.description: The Grants Committee has received the grant proposal for a complete Perl 6 course with exercise by Andrew Shitov.

item.title: What's new on CPAN - May 2019
item.description: One of the most popular monthly blog, every Perl hacker always look forward to.

item.title: Interact with AWS using Perl
item.description: A very detailed discussion how Perl can interact with AWS.

item.title: Perl I never write: snippets
item.description: Handy template expansion system for Perl.

item.title: Perl 5.30 deprecates use of my() in a false conditional
item.description: Use of my() in false condition is now deprecated in Perl v5.30.

item.title: How to revert your git commits without panicking
item.description: I know how stressfull it is when you have to clear out commits from Git cleanly.

item.title: Simple Event Correlator v2.8.2
item.description: SEC is a lightweight and platform-independent event correlator which runs as a single process. The user can start it as a daemon, employ it in shell pipelines, execute it interactively in a terminal, run many SEC processes simultaneously for different tasks, and use it in a wide variety of other ways.

item.title: Roles and Responsibilities in Scrum
item.description: Mark shares the importance of Roles and Responsibilities in Scrum.

item.title: Your Linux Can Get Hacked Just by Opening a File in Vim or Neovim Editor
item.description: Must read for any Vim user.

item.title: Make your business stick! StickerYou has an exclusive discount for all Perl Weekly subscribers
item.description: StickerYou is your one-stop shop to make your business stick. You can create waterproof stickers, labels, decals, magnets, and more in any size, shape, and order quantity. Whether youâ€™re a freelancer or aspiring entrepreneur, StickerYou makes it easy for you to stick your logo on everything and create brand awareness, or just to make stickers for personal expression. Use code PERL10 at checkout for a 10% discount on your order.

item.title: #412 - The Perl Conference in Pittsburgh 2019
item.description:
Hi there

If you happen to be in and around Pittsburgh between June 16-21 then do attend the conference. For more information, checkout the page for more information.

Please do share your experience with us at the end of the conference.

Have a great and fun week.
